This study aims to examine the association of social isolation, loneliness and their combined effects with incident cancer. Methods This study utilized data from the UK Biobank (UKB), which is a population-based prospective cohort. Social isolation and loneliness were assessed through self-reported questionnaires. Cancer cases were identified by linking to cancer registries. Results A total of 430,376 participants were included, during a mean follow-up of 14.32 years, 45,131 participants were diagnosed with cancer. Compared to participants in least isolated group, those in most isolated group had significantly higher risks of cancer of lip, oral cavity and pharynx (HR 1.32, 95% CI 1.11–1.58), cancer of digestive organs (HR 1.10, 95% CI 1.03–1.16), cancer of respiratory and intrathoracic organs (HR 1.17, 95% CI 1.07–1.28), breast cancer (HR 1.11, 95% CI 1.04–1.18), cancer of female genital organs (HR 1.23, 95% CI 1.09–1.38), and cancer of urinary tract (HR 1.31, 95% CI 1.17–1.46). However, the most isolated group had lower risks of cancer of mesothelial and soft tissue (HR 0.80, 95% CI 0.64–0.99), prostate cancer (HR 0.88, 95% CI 0.83–0.94). Individuals with loneliness had a significantly increased risk of cancer of urinary tract (HR 1.19, 95% CI 1.01–1.40), but a reduced risk of cancer of skin (HR 0.76, 95% CI 0.61–0.93). Conclusions Social isolation and loneliness were independently associated with incident cancer, with implications for early effective cancer prevention. By examining these relationships in this large-scale population, we aim to provide new insights into cancer prevention through the lens of social determinants of health. Materials and methods Study design and participants This study used data from the UKB, a prospective, population-based cohort comprising over 500,000 participants aged 37–73 years who were recruited between 2006 and 2010. Participants finished an electronic questionnaire and a verbal interview, physical measurements, and provided biological samples from 22 assessment centers across England, Scotland, and Wales [ 31 In the current study, 502,370 UK adults were initially screened. After excluding individuals with missing data on loneliness or social isolation ( n n S1 Assessment of exposure The exposures of interest included social isolation and loneliness. Social isolation was evaluated through objective indicators of social connections, focusing on the frequency of social interactions and involvement in social activities [ 10 11 32 33 S1 Assessment of outcome In this study, the primary outcomes were first primary incident cancers. Cancers were ascertained through record linkage to the cancer registries in England, Wales, and Scotland, which provide comprehensive data on cancer registrations and deaths [ 34 S2 Assessment of covariates The selection of potential covariates was guided by established confounders identified in prior epidemiological studies, followed by multicollinearity diagnostics. Consequently, the following variables were included in the final analysis: age, sex, ethnicity, household income, educational level, employment status, smoking status, alcohol consumption, sun exposure time, dietary patterns, sleep patterns, Townsend deprivation index, and self-reported medical conditions (including hypertension, dyslipidemia, and family history of cancer). Household annual income was categorised into four levels: < £18,000, £18,000– £51,999, ≥ £52,000, and unknown (GBP per annum). The Townsend deprivation index was derived from four socioeconomic indicators: unemployment, overcrowded household, non-car ownership, and non-home ownership [ 35 36 37 S3 S4 S5 Statistical analyses Person-years of follow-up were calculated from the baseline survey date to the earliest occurrence of one of the following events: the first cancer diagnosis, death, or the end of the study. Basic characteristics were presented as mean (standard deviation, SD) or median (interquartile range, IQR) for continuous variables and frequencies (percentages) for categorical variables. Statistical differences in continuous variables were evaluated using t χ 2 S6 The association between exposure (social isolation and loneliness) and incident cancer was examined using multivariable Cox proportional hazards models. The results were presented as hazard ratios (HRs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). The proportional-hazard assumptions were verified using Schoenfeld’s test and by plotting residuals.The association between social isolation, loneliness, and cancer risk was evaluated through both main-effect and interaction models. The analyses were adjusted for the following covariates: age, sex, ethnicity, household income, educational level, Townsend deprivation index, body mass index (BMI), employment status, smoking status, alcohol consumption, sun exposure time, healthy diet score, healthy sleep score, family cancer history, and history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. For models analyzing breast cancer and cancers of the female genital organs, additional adjustments were made for menopausal status, HRT use, and parity. These adjustments ensured a comprehensive evaluation of the associations while accounting for potential confounding factors. Furthermore, subgroup analyses were carried out, with stratification based on age (< 60 or ≥ 60 years), sex (male or female), ethnicity (White British or other), BMI (< 25 kg/m 2 2 2 In addition, two sensitivity analyses were performed to evaluate the robustness of the findings. We excluded individuals with a family history of cancer to minimize the potential influence of genetic factors. Additionally, we excluded those diagnosed with cancer within the initial 3 years of follow-up to address the impact of reverse causality. The analysis was performed in multivariable model (age, sex, ethnicity, household income, college/university degree, Townsend deprivation index, BMI, employment status, current smoking status, current alcohol consumption, sun exposure time, healthy diet score, healthy sleep score, family history of cancer, and history of hypertension and dyslipidemia) A B Subgroups and sensitivity analyses Nearly consistent results were observed in the subgroup analyses (Supplemental Table S8 29 In the sensitivity analyses, after excluding participants with a family history of cancer (Supplemental Table S30 31 S32 33 Discussion Our study represents the first comprehensive assessment of the impact of social isolation and loneliness on a wide range of cancer types within a large-scale prospective cohort, marking a novel contribution to the field. The key findings can be summarized as follows: loneliness and social isolation were separately and jointly associated with higher risks of developing most types of cancer, while being linked to lower risks of prostate and skin cancer. Additionally, social isolation was found to play a more significant role in estimating cancer risk compared to loneliness. While previous research has provided important insights into the relationship between loneliness, social isolation, and the risk of specific cancers, certain limitations still need to be addressed. For instance, previous studies have primarily focused on the individual associations of either social isolation or loneliness with cancer, without exploring their potential joint effects. Additionally, these studies were limited to only a few specific types of cancer, rather than examining a broad range of cancer types. Other concerns, such as insufficient follow-up durations and relatively small sample sizes, may further undermine the reliability of the conclusions drawn from prior research. In our study, we have addressed these limitations and provided a more comprehensive understanding of the associations between social isolation, loneliness and a wide range of cancer risks. Our study found that individuals with the most social isolation were at a higher risk of cancer than those with the least social isolation. Our study findings align with previous research that demonstrated low social support was linked to a higher risk of colorectal cancer incidence and mortality among men [ 27 38 29 In this large, population-based cohort study involving 430,376 participants, we found that loneliness elevated the risk of urinary tract cancer, but no significant positive or negative associations for the rest. A previous case-control study conducted in China enrolled a total of 324 urological cancer patients and 100 healthy controls. The study revealed that urological cancer patients experienced higher levels of loneliness and reduced spiritual well-being compared to healthy controls [ 30 Intriguingly, our study suggested that social isolation was associated with a lower risk of developing prostate cancer, the same goes for loneliness and skin cancer, which was beyond our thoughts. Elovainio Marko et al. came to the same conclusion with us, they assessed cancer risk among all Finnish people over 40, their study concluded that men living alone was associated with lower risk of prostate cancer and skin melanoma [ 29 28 39 Our study indicated that social isolation was more strongly associated with cancer than loneliness, consistent with others [ 33 40 40 33 41 Several mechanisms could explain the observed association between social isolation, loneliness, and incident cancer. First, traditional risk factors, underlying diseases, and unhealthy lifestyles might act as mediators or moderators [ 42 36 43 44 20 From a public health perspective, our findings emphasize the need to develop and validate reliable tools for screening social isolation and loneliness. A comprehensive, multi-level approach that integrates interventions at the individual, community, and societal levels, is crucial for effectively alleviating the burden of social isolation and loneliness. Strategies at the individual level include psychological therapies, social skills training, and socialization supporting [ 45 Although this study has notable strengths, such as its large sample size, reliable assessment of exposure, comprehensive data on covariates, complete follow-up, and inclusion of a wide range of cancer types, certain limitations should be acknowledged. First, although changes over time were acknowledged, we were unable to directly evaluate the potential underestimation of risks associated with these changes during the follow-up period. Second, participants in the UKB were predominantly of European descent, restricting the generalizability of the results to diverse ethnic and racial groups. Third, social isolation and loneliness could be affected by undiagnosed cancer or poor health at baseline. Fourth, observational study cannot draw causality between social isolation, loneliness and the incidence of cancer, which warrants more well-conducted intervention studies to verify. Despite these limitations, our study contributes to the growing literature demonstrating the association of social isolation, loneliness and a wide range of cancer risk. Future studies should incorporate randomized controlled trials to alleviate loneliness and social isolation among individuals experiencing or at high risk of these unhealthy psychological conditions. This approach will generate more robust evidence regarding the causality of the association between loneliness, social isolation and cancer. Conclusion This study provides novel evidence linking social isolation and loneliness to increased risks of a wide range of cancers, underscoring the urgent need to address these psychosocial factors as integral components of cancer prevention strategies.
